awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Directed Self-Assembly of Multifunctional Polymer Nanoreactors for Sustainable Chemical Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award will pioneer nanoscale chemical processing to achieve complex chemical products, such as, pharmaceuticals, with significantly reduced hazardous waste.  Producing pharmaceuticals generates large amounts of hazardous waste, as much as 100 times more than desired product.  Aggressive solvents account for the majority of waste.  While solvents are necessary for chemical reaction products, their largest quantities are used in product isolation, separation, and purification.  New discoveries in multifunctional reactors capable of reaction and separation will improve process efficiency and reduce waste.  This award supports fundamental research to provide the knowledge needed to develop multifunctional polymer nanoreactors that facilitate accelerated reaction and spontaneous, energy efficient and solvent-free product isolation.  Ultimately, the nanoreactors would lead to efficient and sustainable manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and basic chemicals from biomass.  Advances in sustainable manufacturing technologies will benefit the U.S. economy and society.  The scientific discoveries will be integrated with advanced training in multifunctional nanoreactor technology and sustainable chemical manufacturing for undergraduate and graduate students. The technical training will be coupled with community outreach to broaden participation of underrepresented groups and enhance engineering education through partnering with Higher Achievement of Richmond and the Science Museum of Virginia.

The ability to perform conventional unit operations,e.g., fixed bed reactions, and liquid-liquid extractions, on the nanoscale would improve the safety, efficiency and sustainability of liquid phase chemical processing.  This award will investigate a new class of multifunctional polymer nanoreactors that combine reaction and product isolation by spontaneous phase separation. The approach is to self-assemble polymer-nanoparticle catalyst nanoreactors in confined impinging jet mixers. Modular selection of the polymer components will lead to the understanding of (a) how polymer properties affect nanoreactor self-assembly and (b) how polymer/reactant/product interactions affect reaction kinetics and transport.  The nanoreactors will be used for oxidation reactions of increasing complexity to perform multiple reaction and separation steps within a single nanoreactor.  Based on the experimental results, a theoretical model to describe nanoscale chemical processing will be established.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project was to discover a new class of multifunctional, polymer nanoreactors to improve the efficiency and sustainability of liquid phase chemical processing.  Specifically, we aimed to achieve reaction and product isolation by spontaneous phase separation from the polymer microenvironment driven by chemical potential gradients in order to minimize waste, avoid hazardous solvents, and eliminate separation agents.  New methods polymer self-assembly were established to create tunable nanoreactors encapsulating metal nanoparticle catalysts with modular selection of the polymer components. Polymer directed self-assembly was used to produce nanoreactors with various hydrophobic microenvironments.  The focus has been understanding the effect of the polymer microenvironment on apparent reactor performance.  The apparent catalytic performance was strongly affected by the microenvironment of the nanoreactor.  For example, the apparent reaction rate (per surface area) using nanoreactors with castor oil cores was nearly 8-fold greater than polystyrene (750 g/mol, PS 750) cores.  The apparent rate acceleration can be attributed to differences in reactant solubility rather than differences in mass transfer or intrinsic kinetics, i.e., higher reactant solubility enhances apparent reaction rates.  Experimentally, the ability of amphiphilic polymer nanoreactors dispersed in water to facilitate two reactions in one pot with spontaneous precipitation of the product from the reaction mixture has been demonstrated.  Specifically, conversion of 4-nitrophenol to 4-aminophenol followed by conversion of the 4-aminophenol with benzaldehyde with polymer nanoreactors incorporating gold nanoparticles as a model reaction was achieved  The reaction occurred in water at ambient conditions; the desired 4-benzylideneaminophenol product spontaneously precipitated from the reaction mixture while the nanoreactors remained stable in dispersion. A 65% isolated yield was achieved.  Furthermore, the amphiphilic polymer nanoreactor structure facilitated isolation of the product from the nanoparticle catalyst.  Specifically, purity of the precipitated product was twofold higher for the nanoreactors compared to the other ligands. The catalyst stability was also improved; fourfold more gold was retained in the dispersion. Overall, this work demonstrates that amphiphilic polymer nanoreactors are a promising approach for combined reaction and separation and could be a valuable tool in green chemical process.  To expand the types of catalysts that can be incorporated into the nanoreactors, the effect of electrostatic interactions on polymer directed self-assembly was investigated. Tools in natural language processing are being used to identify novel cascade reactions and ultimately broaden the products that can be achieved using nanoscale chemical engineering.   Further, small molecules have been incorporated into the self-assembly process and their release mechanism has been examined to understand product transport from the nanoreactors. More broadly, understanding the transport mechanisms from this platform of self-assembled materials can be used to for controlled release applications, e.g. to achieve cancer medicines with improved potency.  Overall, this research could enable a new paradigm of sustainable chemical processing with reduced energy requirements and solvent waste for a range of applications.

This project provided research opportunities for six graduate students and 15 undergraduate students.  To date, this award has resulted in 15 peer-reviewed manuscripts and three graduate dissertations.  The results have been presented at numerous national and international conferences.  The project was used as a platform to introduce undergraduate and graduate students to concepts in Sustainable Materials and Manufacturing through existing and newly developed courses offered by the PI.  For example, green chemistry metrics were introduces in the core chemical engineering curriculum (Material Balances) and a course in Sustainable Chemical Engineering was developed.  Major topics discussed were: renewable energy, sustainable chemical processing, and waste valorization.  Undergraduate and graduate students were trained in technical communication (writing and presenting).  The research activities were used as an educational outreach platform for students at all levels to learn about Advanced Manufacturing of polymer materials. Educational activities were performed by the PI, graduate students, and undergraduate students at Richmond Public Schools and the Science Museum of Virginia (Girls in Science event).  Aspects of this project have been covered by Virginia Public Media (through Instagram).
